name: Who Really Wrote Shakespeare? Quiz | People | 10 Questions

questions.text: The mysterious death of this writer (at approximately the time that Shakespeare was coming into prominence) has led some people to suspect that this man's death was faked. Who was he?
questions.explanation:
Christopher Marlowe.

	Marlowe was almost certainly working as some type of political operative in the highly political Elizabethan world. The man who killed him (and the man's companions) were also probably involved in "spying" activities. His death came at a time when he was under investigation for charges of heresy -- a very serious charge in those days. It has been suggested that he faked his death and resumed writing, using the name Shakespeare as an alias.

questions.text: Which of the following had a son named "Hamnet"?
questions.explanation:
William Shakespeare.

	Unfortunately, Hamnet's life proved more difficult than that of the fictional Hamlet: Shakespeare's only son, one of a pair of twins, died at approximately 11 years of age.

questions.text: Many people who believe that this man was the true author of Shakespeare's works refer to the presence of "ciphers" in the work for support.
questions.explanation:
Francis Bacon.

	A woman named Delia Bacon - no relation to Francis - is credited with being the first to "find" the ciphers. The efforts have been so tortured, however, that they hurt (rather than help) the arguments in support of Francis Bacon.

questions.text: Which of these prominent Americans doubted that Shakespeare was the true author of the works attributed to him?
questions.explanation:
All of these.

	One can add to this list names such as Sigmund Freud, Ralph Waldo Emerson, John Greenleaf Whitier, and others.

questions.text: The protagonist in "Hamlet" has his mother re-marry quickly after his father's death. He encounters pirates at sea. He is betrothed to the daughter of a court advisor. Which of the following men experienced these events in his own life?
questions.explanation:
Earl of Oxford.

	Oxford's life is similar to Hamlet's in terms of the death of a father and the quick re-marriage of a mother (to a "lesser"). Hamlet was engaged to Ophelia, daughter of Polonius (royal councillor). Oxford was engaged to the daughter of Lord Burghley (who is believed to be the "model" for Polonius). Burghley was a key minister and advisor to the royal court.

questions.text: Why would a nobleman write Shakespeare's works and let another man take credit for being the author?
options: Being a writer was not a well-respected activity
Being a writer was inappropriate for a member of the nobility
Certain "injudicious" comments in the plays could have been awkward (or worse) if attribued to a nobleman
questions.explanation:
All of these.

	The comments are self-explanatory in this instance.

questions.text: One challenge to Shakespeare's authorship argues that he could not have had experience with the world of the nobility discussed in many of the plays. Who else also lacked experience as a nobleman?
questions.explanation:
Christopher Marlowe.

	Essex and Oxford were Earls; Derby was a Lord. Marlowe, like Shakespeare, was the son of a working man.

questions.text: One of Shakespeare's plays makes reference to a "great reckoning in a small room". What incident is probably being referenced?
options: The exploration and colonization efforts of Raleigh
questions.explanation:
Marlowe's death in a brawl.

	Marlowe's death was officially said to be in a dispute over a bill. (A "reckoning"). The "small room" may refer to the fact that the dispute occurred in a room in a private house (where people could go to lunch, etc.) (It has been suggested that it was a "safe house" for "agents" such as Marlowe and the others.) Is this reference in the play some form of hint or "inside joke"?

questions.text: Which of these life experiences is suggestive of Oxford as the true author of Shakespeare's works?
questions.explanation:
All of these.

	Oxford, a courtier, traveled, experienced combat, was trained as a lawyer and was also familiar with the ways of the nobility. Shakespeare was not.

questions.text: Which of these items might lead one to doubt Shakespeare's authorship?
options: His will failed to make reference to any books in his possession
There were no eulogies upon his death
His children were quite probably illiterate
questions.explanation:
All of these.

	All of these matters have been raised by the challengers to Shakespeare's authorship.
